10.1016/j.mcat.2023.113786 The Author(s) Fig. 1 Left: Oxidative coupling of styrenes 1 with aryl sulfone 2 catalyzed by AgNO3 or Cu catalysts (this work). Right: general conceptual approach based on the speciation of the metal catalyst. Fig 1 Fig. 2 Substrate scope for the oxidative cross–coupling reaction of different styrenes 1a–m with phenyl sulfone 2 catalyzed by CuCO3 under the conditions described in Table 1. Isolated yields. Fig 2 Fig. 3 Kinetic plots for the oxidative cross–coupling reaction of styrene 1a with phenyl sulfone 2 catalyzed by either CuCO3 or AgNO3 (15 mol%) under the conditions described in Fig. 1, in the presence of visible light. Error bars account for a 5% uncertainty. Fig 3 Fig. 4 Tentative mechanism for the oxidative cross–coupling reaction of styrene 1a with phenyl sulfone 2 catalyzed by either CuCO3 or AgNO3 in toluene solvent at 100 °C. Fig 4 Fig. 5 Results for the reuses (left) and leaching (right) of zeolite Cu–NaY as a catalyst for the oxidative cross–coupling reaction of styrene 1a with phenyl sulfone 2 under the optimized reaction conditions employed in this work. Error bars account for a 5% uncertainty. Fig 5 Fig. 6 Crystal structure of Cu–MOF [58]. Views along the c (left) and b (middle) axes, and a perspective view of one single channel (right). The ligands of the coordination 3D network are depicted as grey sticks whereas copper atoms are represented as cyan spheres. The compensation Ni2+ cations and water molecules are represented as yellow and red spheres, respectively. Yellow surfaces are used to highlight the compensation Ni2+ cations within MOF´s channels. Fig 6 Fig. 7 Results for the reuses (left) and leaching (right) of zeolite Cu2+(SACs)–MOF as a catalyst for the oxidative cross–coupling reaction of styrene 1a with phenyl sulfone 2 under the optimized reaction conditions employed in this work. Error bars account for a 5 % uncertainty. Fig 7 Fig. 8 Substrate scope for the oxidative cross–coupling reaction of different styrenes 1a–l with phenyl sulfone 2 catalyzed by Cu–NaY and Cu2+–MOF, respectively, under the optimized reaction conditions employed in this work. Isolated yields. Fig 8 Table 1 Catalytic results for the oxidative cross–coupling reaction of styrene 1a with phenyl sulfone 2, exposed or not to visible light, under reported conditions [17]. Visible light refers to the typical light in a laboratory (i.e. fumehood light), without any on–purpose device. The reactants disappearance and product appearance were followed by gas–chromatography (GC). [a] The reaction does not proceed if 3Å molecular sieves are added to the reaction. Table 1 Entry Catalyst Light 3a (yield, %) 1 None Yes 6.5 2 None 3.9 3[a] AgNO3 Yes 72.3 4 None 15.8 5 Mn(OAc)3·2H2O Yes 8.5 6 Fe2(SO4)3 Yes 27.6 7 NiCl2 Yes 40.3 8 Ni(OAc)2 Yes 11.2 9 CoSO4 Yes 11.8 10 CoCl2 Yes 15.7 11 Co(OAc)2 Yes 1.2 12 Co3O4 Yes 15.0 13 ZnCl2 Yes 3.6 14 ZnSO4 Yes 10.4 15[a] CuCO3 Yes 53.2 Table 2 Catalytic results for the oxidative cross–coupling reaction of styrene 1a with phenyl sulfone 2 catalyzed by Cu2+ (SACs)–supported materials, under the optimized reaction conditions shown in Table 1. Oxidative couplings in organic synthesis are typically performed with unrecoverable precious metal catalysts in solution. Here we show that CuCO3, Cu–supported zeolites and Cu–metal organic frameworks (MOFs) can replace AgNO3 as a catalyst for the oxidative coupling of styrenes with aryl sulfones, to give styrenyl sulfones. The single Cu atoms supported in zeolites show higher catalytic activity than the Cu salt as the basicity of the zeolite framework increases, to match the carbonate salt, and when embedded directly into a MOFs´ walls with oxamate ligands (thus with the proper electronic environment) they can be recycled for at least five times without any depletion in catalytic activity. These results showcase not only the substitution of a noble metal (Ag) by an abundant metal (Cu) in a metal–catalyzed oxidative coupling reaction, but also going from a salt to a supported solid catalyst, of high significance from a sustainable point of view. Graphical abstract Cu in the form of salt (CuCO3) and supported either on zeolites or a MOF catalyzes the oxidative coupling of styrenes with phenyl sulfone, to substitute the benchmark AgNO3 catalyst in solution. Mechanistic studies show that single atoms of Cu2+ (SACs) are the active sites. The Cu-MOF could be reused at least five times without depletion in final yield of the coupled product, despite the aggressive oxidative conditions typically employed for this reaction. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Single–atom catalyst (SAC) Oxidative coupling Copper catalysis Metal organic frameworks Zeolites Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The substitution of catalysts based on expensive precious metals by first–raw inexpensive metals is a high significance from a sustainable point of view, moreover if the latter can be easily recycled [1–3]. In particular, typically unrecoverable precious metal catalysts for oxidative cross–coupling reactions are difficult to either be supported on solids or be replaced by solid–supported earth–abundant metals [4–6], since the harsh reaction conditions needed for the C–H activation process are only achieved with strong oxidants, which promote the leaching of any supported metal catalyst [7–13]. In this regard, metal single atom catalysts (SACs) in microporous frameworks have shown a superior stability towards leaching compared to supported metal complexes and nanoparticles, since the constrained space of the support–embedded SAC solid allows to better retain the metal atom on the solid surface during reaction [14–16]. Here we show that the oxidative coupling of styrenes 1 with aryl sulfone 2, a reaction typically catalyzed by AgNO3 as a catalyst and 2,2,6,6–tetramethylpiperidine 1–oxyl (TEMPO)/K2S2O8 as an oxidant mixture in solution [17], can be carried out not only with simple Cu salts but also with Cu SACs in zeolites and MOFs (Fig. 1 , left), and that the latter is an effective and recyclable catalyst for the reaction. Mechanistic studies will show that AgNO3 is just a precursor of catalytically active ultrasmall Ag clusters, which are very difficult to support, while the Cu SACs act similarly in solution or supported. Thus, our approach here is based on the speciation of the catalytic metal species and goes from an unrecoverable precious metal to a recyclable common metal (Fig. 1, right). Functionalized styrenes 1 are building blocks in organic synthesis, which give access to a plethora of compounds such as substituted alkanes, cyclopropanes, polystyrenes, carbonyl compounds, and other styrenes, to name a few [18–22]. For instance, vinyl sulfones 3 are transformable to a variety of organic products after SO2 extrusion, sulfone exchange or reduction, and carbon–sulfur coupling [23,24]. However, the synthesis of vinyl sulfones 3 depends heavily on highly energetic compounds such as alkynes or tosyl hydrazones [25–27], and generally require precious metals or hypervalent iodine compounds to enable the transformation [28,29]. A direct synthesis from simple and commercially available styrenes 1 and aryl sulfone 2 is highly desirable but, to our knowledge and as mentioned above, the more efficient catalytic system reported so far for this transformation is based on unrecoverable Ag salts [17]. In our hands, the reaction in Fig. 1 with AgNO3 showed reproducibility problems. Different sources of AgNO3 gave inconsistent results and, furthermore (see below), the exposure of the reaction to visible light is key for the reaction, thus a new source of irreproducibility under standard reaction conditions was found. We show here that CuCO3 can play the role of AgNO3 in this transformation, without those irreproducibility issues. Comparative mechanistic studies will show that CuCO3 activates the styrene derivative as AgNO3 does, indeed, so strongly that can easily trigger other secondary reactions [30–32]. The catalytic activity of Cu in solution for a coupling reaction via C–H activation is not surprising [33], however, opens the door in this case for the design of solid catalysts. Once we know that Cu2+ can catalyze the reaction, different Cu–zeolites and a Cu–MOF were prepared and tested in the reaction, and the Cu SAC in the MOF showed a high catalytic efficiency and recyclability, to give high yields for different vinyl sulfones 3. Comparatively, AgNO3 in solution requires higher metal loadings to generate in–situ Ag clusters and effect the transformation, which avoids an easy supporting. These results illustrate how a particular first–raw transition metal SAC can play the catalytic role of a noble metal salt in solution with higher efficiency, better reproducibility and translation to a recyclable solid. 2 Materials and methods General. Reagents were obtained from commercial sources (Merck–Aldrich) and used without further purification otherwise indicated. Physical techniques for organic compound characterization. GC and GC–MS chromatography were performed in chromatographs with 25 m capillary columns filled with 1 or 5 wt % phenylsilicone (Shimadzu GC–2025, Agilent GC 6890 N coupled with Agilent MS–5973). 1H, 13C, 19F and DEPT nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectra were recorded at room temperature on 300 or 400 MHz spectrometers using the appropriate deuterated solvent. Absorption spectra were recorded on a Cary 300 UV–Vis spectrophotometer (UV0811M209, Varian) in 1 cm wide cuvettes, and fluorescence spectra were obtained with a LP S–220B (Photon Technology International) equipped with 75 W Xe lamp. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT–IR) spectra were recorded on a spectrophotometer equipped with an attenuated total reflection instrument (JASCO FT/IR–4700), by dropping a small sample of the dissolved organic compound in dichloromethane on the ATR crystal and measuring from 400 to 4000 cm–1 after leaving to evaporate the solvent for 1 min. Physical techniques for solid characterization. The metal content of the samples was determined by inductively coupled plasma–atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP–AES), after disaggregating the solids in aqua regia and later diluted before analysis. Diffuse reflectance UV–Visible spectrophotometry (DR UV–vis) in the region comprised between 190 and 1100 nm was recorded at room temperature on a spectrophotometer equipped with an integrating sphere. The mixture was contained in a quartz cell with 1 mm path length; the layer can therefore be regarded as infinitely thick, as required by the Kubelka–Munk theory. Absorbance values (Al) were calculated from reflectance ones (Rl) according to the Kubelka–Munk transformation: Al = (1–Rl) 2/2Rl. X–ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed on a SPECS spectrometer equipped with a Phoibos 150 MCD–9 analyser using a non–monochromatic Mg KR (1,253.6 eV) X–ray source working at 50 W. The C1s peak has been set at 284.5 eV as the internal reference for the peak positions in the XPS spectra. X–Ray diffraction (XRD) spectra of the support and supported catalyst were recorded in a CubiX PRO (PAN Analytical) spectrometer, with a Cu K(α) radiation source, 1.5406 Å wavelength. FT–IR spectra were recorded on a spectrophotometer equipped with an attenuated total reflection instrument (JASCO FT/IR–4700), by dropping the solid on the ATR crystal, pressing, and measuring from 400 to 4000 cm–1. Electronic paramagnetic resonance (EPR) measurements were performed at -170 °C using an EMX–12 Bruker spectrometer working at the X band, with a frequency modulation of 100 kHz and 1G amplitude. Portions at different times of each reactions were introduced inside an EPR quartz probe cell and were measured. Raman spectra were recorded at room temperature with a 514 nm laser excitation on a Renishaw Raman Spectrometer (“in via”) equipped with a CCD detector. Typical reaction procedure for oxidative styrene couplings with Ag catalysts in solution (reproductions). Product 3a was prepared following the reaction scheme in Fig. 1. Styrene 1a (1 eq, 0.4 mmol) and sulfone 2 (1 eq, 0.4 mmol) were introduced in a glass reactor equipped with a magnetic stirrer, together with K2S2O8 (2 eq, 0.8 mmol), TEMPO (0.2 eq, 0.08 mmol), AgNO3 (15 mol%, 0.06 mmol) and 2 mL of toluene, and allowed to react overnight (18 h) at 100 °C under N2 atmosphere. After that time, the resulting mixture is quenched by the addition of water, extracted with dichloromethane and dried over Na2SO4. The products obtained are characterized by GC–MS. Typical reaction procedure for oxidative styrene couplings with Cu catalysts in solution. The reaction procedure is the same as above for AgNO3, only that the silver catalyst (15 mol%) is replaced by the required amount of copper catalyst. Monitoring of the Ag–catalyzed coupling reaction by UV–Vis absorption and UV–Visible emission (fluorimetry) spectrophotometry. The photophysical measurements were performed at room temperature in a quartz cell of 1.0 cm optical path length. Aliquots of the reaction were taken at different reaction times and placed in the quartz cell, which was then closed to measure the corresponding absorption and fluorescence spectrum on a Cary 300 UV–Vis and a LP S–220B spectrophotometer respectively, the latter equipped with 75 W Xe lamp and irradiating between 240 and 260 nm. Determination of the reaction orders during the Ag and Cu–catalyzed reactions. To determine the rate equations, five kinetics were performed, following the reaction procedure detailed above. For each reagent, the amount of one of them is varied while the other reagent amounts remain constant, in order to determine its reaction order under pseudo–stationary conditions. The procedure is repeated for each reagent to obtain the reaction rate. Kinetic experiments with deuterated styrene. To determine the kinetic isotopic effect (KIE), kinetics with deuterated styrene–d8 were performed, following the reaction procedures described above with Ag or Cu catalysts in solution. General procedure for the preparation of basic zeolites and Cu2+ incorporation. Commercially available H–USY zeolite (Si/Al= 15) was treated with a 1M aqueous solution of Cs+ acetate, to give the corresponding Cs+–zeolite (CsY). Then, the HY, NaY and CsY zeolites were cationically exchanged with an aqueous solution of Cu(OAc)2. Finally, the zeolites were calcined at 450 °C. General procedure for the preparation of Ni–NaY zeolite. Commercially available Y zeolite, in Na+–form, was treated with a 0.1M aqueous solution of Ni2+ acetate at room temperature for 20 h. Then the zeolite was filtered, washed with deionized water and dry at 100 °C, to give the corresponding Ni–zeolite. In this way, Ni2+ is homogenously distributed along the zeolite channels and cavities. Final Ni content is 4.5 wt%. Reaction procedure for styrene couplings with Cu solid catalysts. Reagent styrene (1 eq, 0.05 mmol) and aryl sulfone (1 eq, 0.05 mmol) were introduced in a small glass vial with a magnetic stirrer, together with K2S2O8 (2 eq, 0.1 mmol), TEMPO (0.2 eq, 0.01 mmol), Cu solid catalysts (5 mg, 15 mol% Cu) and 0.25 mL of toluene and allowed to react for 24 h under N2 at 100 °C. After that time, the resulting mixture is quenched by the addition of water, extracted with dichloromethane and dried over Na2SO4. Products are characterized by GC–MS. Leaching tests. Following the general reaction procedure above, the hot reaction mixture was filtered at intermediate conversion, through a 0.25 μm Teflon filter. Filtrates were placed into a new glass reactor equipped with a magnetic stirrer and fresh insoluble aryl sulfone and K2S2O8, and placed under N2 and reaction temperature. The filtrates were periodically analyzed by GC, comparing the results obtained with the solid catalyst still in. Typical reaction procedure for reusing. Reuses of the Cu solid catalyst were performed after separating the solids at the end of reaction by centrifugation and washing the solid mixture with deionized water and methanol (three times) to remove excess styrene, aryl sulfone, TEMPO, K2S2O8, and any soluble product. Subsequently, the Cu solid catalyst is dried in oven at 100 °C overnight and directly use in the next reaction. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Oxidative coupling of styrene 1a with aryl sulfone 2 catalyzed by Cu salts 3.1.1 Catalyst screening with different first–raw transition metal salts: from Ag to Cu Table 1 shows the catalytic results for the synthesis of vinyl sulfone 3a with different metal catalysts, after performing the reaction under the optimized reaction conditions reported in the literature but exposing or not the reaction mixture to visible light [17]. The reaction barely proceeds in the absence of any metal (entries 1–2), however, it does proceed when AgNO3 is in the presence of light, to give a yield of 3a as reported [17]. However, reproductions with different commercial AgNO3 batches gave disparate results, most of them disappointing, with yields <20 %. The reaction with the catalytically active AgNO3 batches was then performed in the absence of light, and the reaction did not work in any case (entry 4). These results indicate that the Ag–catalyzed reaction is very sensitive to the Ag source employed and the presence or not of light, suggesting that AgNO3 is not the truly catalyst of the oxidative coupling reaction but just a precursor. To further study this hypothesis, the reaction was in–situ monitored by absorption (UV–vis) and emission (fluorescence) UV–Vis spectroscopy (Figs S1 and S2, respectively) [34]. The results show that ultrasmall Ag clusters [35], but not Ag nanoparticles [36], are rapidly formed under the successful reaction conditions, which indicate that AgNO3 evolves to catalytically active ultrasmall clusters. In accordance with this, a house–made Ag on Al2O3 catalyst, composed of supported Ag nanoparticles with an average size >5 nm (Fig. S3) [36], was completely inactive for the reaction, and another metal salt prone to form ultrasmall clusters in solution such as AuCl [37,38], showed significant yields of the coupling product 3a (Table S1). These results support that AgNO3 evolves to catalytically active Ag clusters under very particular reaction conditions, which severely hampers the design of a solid–supported Ag catalyst for the oxidative coupling. With these results in hand, we turned our attention to first–raw metal catalysts, where the action of visible light and the formation of clusters during reaction should be less relevant. Mn(OAc)3 (entry 5), Fe2(SO4)3 and other Fe salts (entry 6 and Table S1), Ni salts (entries 7–8) and Co salts (entries 9–12) showed low to moderate catalytic results. Remarkably, CuCO3 gave consistently a 53 % yield of the coupling product 3a (entry 15). Several reproductions gave similar results. Other Cu salts (CuCl, CuCl2,…) were less active than CuCO3 (Table S1). It must be noticed that water must play a role in the reaction, since the use of 3Å molecular sieves together with either CuCO3 or AgNO3 inhibited the product formation. 3.1.2 Substrate scope CuCO3 can now be employed as a catalyst for the oxidative cross–coupling reaction of different styrene derivatives with phenyl sulfone 2 (Fig. 2 ), under the reaction conditions shown above (i.e. Table 1). The results show that different functionalities such as methyl (3b–c), halides (3d–i), ester (3j), aldehyde (3k), ether (3l) and nitro (3m), in different positions of the aryl ring including the sterically encumbered ortho position (3c,i) are tolerated during reaction, to give consistent yields around 50–60 %. The cases where the yield is low roughly correspond to the more electron withdrawing styrenes (i.e. products 3f, 3k and 3m; with CF3, COH and NO2 substituting groups, respectively), which can be due to an inefficient coupling with the somewhat more electrophilic sulfonyl radical. 3.1.3 Catalytic active species of Ag and Cu Experiments focused to better understanding the reasons why CuCO3 can substitute AgNO3 as a catalyst for the oxidative coupling of 1a and 2 in solution, were then accomplished. First, comparative kinetics plots for AgNO3 and CuCO3, under exactly the same reaction conditions, show that the initial rate for CuCO3 (thus the initial turnover frequency, TOF0) is nearly the double that AgNO3, without considering the aggregation of Ag, with >95% selectivity towards product 3a in both cases (Fig. 3 ). The small amount of by–products found correspond to dimers and trimers of styrene 1a [30]. The kinetic points for AgNO3 are the best obtained in our hands during a kinetic study while, in contrast, the CuCO3 results were highly reproducible. These results confirm the feasibility of CuCO3 to substitute AgNO3 as an effective catalyst for the oxidative coupling of styrene 1a with sulfone 2. The rate equation for both AgNO3 and CuCO3–catalyzed reactions was then determined from the initial rates of kinetic experiments, after varying the concentration of each reagent during reaction, since induction times are not present in the kinetic profile. The results (Fig. S4 for AgNO3 and Fig. S5 for CuCO3) unveiled different rate equations for each metal catalyst, as shown in Eq. (1) and (2). (1) v0= kexp[Ag]2[TEMPO][2][1a]−2 for AgNO3 (2) v0= kexp´[K2S2O8][2][1a]−2 for CuCO3 It can be seen that the reaction rate of the AgNO3–catalyzed reaction is directly proportional to the square of the Ag concentration, in good agreement with the formation of ultrasmall Ag2 dimers during reaction [34,39]. In contrast, the CuCO3–catalyzed reaction follows a linear dependence with the concentration of K2S2O8 and aryl sulfone 2, and an inverse linear dependence with styrene 1a. The concentration of TEMPO and CuCO3 does not influences the initial reaction rate for Cu, and can be included in the experimental constants kexp´. These rate equations are giving some information about the reaction mechanism. In one hand, the fact that the reaction rate is inversely proportional to styrene 1a for both catalysts reflect a strong binding and activation of 1a in the metal site, which is indeed the cause of the oligomerization of 1a. In other words, the oligomerization reaction of styrene 1a increases with the [1a]2, thus our oxidative coupling decreases. In the other hand, the relative catalytic behaviour of CuCO3 and AgNO3 towards 1a is opposite, and while increasing the amount of CuCO3 does not influence the reaction rate for the oxidative cross coupling, the increase in the amount of AgNO3 increases the reaction rate. Indeed, the linear dependence of the reaction rate with [Ag]2 confirms the need of agglomerating Ag during reaction to be catalytically active, thus explaining the high loadings of Ag required in solution. The reaction with Ag is linearly dependent of [TEMPO], which strongly indicates a radical activation of 1a. Electronic paramagnetic resonance (EPR) experiments showed the formation of the PhSO2 radical for the Ag–catalyzed reaction (Fig. S6) [40]. Besides, the EPR experiments also showed the formation of the hydroperoxide radical HOO·, which explains the need of having some water during reaction, and the disappearance of TEMPO during the first minutes of reaction. The formation of HOO· could led to some undesired by–reactions under aerobic conditions, and to check that, the coupling reaction was repeated under an O2 atmosphere [41,42]. The results showed the formation of ketone 4a instead of the alkene product 3a (Fig. S7), supporting the formation of a benzyl radical intermediate [43–46]. A Hammett plot for Cu (Fig. S8) shows a V–shaped curve after testing different p–substituted styrenes, with increasing electron richness. The slope values are ρmax= 1.1078 and ρmin= 0.8169, much lower that for AgNO3 (ρmax=2.6 and ρmin=2.5) [34,39], which indicates that the former does not depend much in the styrene electronics. The different dependency on substrate electronics of the two metal catalysts can be quantified, since the V–shaped curve indicates the adaptability of the metal catalyst to the substrate through the “adapted sensitivity constant” (ρ adap) and the “substrate electronics adaptability of the catalyst” value (SEAC) [34]. For AgNO3, these values were ρ adap= 5.18 and SEAC= 96%, while for CuCO3 these values are ρ adap= 0.29 and SEAC= 13%. The difference is so high that one can soundly affirm that the styrene electronics has much more influence on the Ag–catalyzed than in the Cu–catalyzed mechanism. The kinetic isotopic effect (KIE) was then measured for both metal catalysts, employing styrene–d8 (1a-d8 ) as a substrate. The results (Fig. S9) show a KIE= 1.38 for AgNO3 and a KIE= 1.16 for CuCO3, under exactly the same reaction conditions. It is clear that, for CuCO3, the breaking of the C–H bond does not participate in the rate-determining step of the reaction. For AgNO3, the contribution of the C–H bond in the reaction rate is perhaps significant, although minor anyway. The KIE results are consistent with an early rate-determining step during the oxidative coupling, where the key reactants are sulfone 2 and the metal catalyst. The combined kinetic, EPR and reactive experiments allow us to propose a plausible mechanism for the metal (CuCO3 or AgNO3)–catalyzed reaction (Fig. 4 ). The first step of the reaction is the formation of the phenyl sulfonyl radical 2·, catalyzed by the metal salt. This radical formation is the rate–determining step (rds) for CuCO3, since the corresponding equation rate (Eq. (2) above) only shows 2 and K2S2O8 as the participating reagents. In line with this, the styrene electronics is not relevant (Hammett plot in Fig. S8) and any KIE is not observed (Fig. S9). In contrast, the rds for AgNO3 can be considered the addition–elimination of TEMPO to the intermediate coupled species between 1a and 2·, since the corresponding equation rate (Eq. (1) above) shows also TEMPO, besides 2 and K2S2O8, as a participating reagent for the reaction rate. In line with this proposal, TEMPO disappears in the initial points of the kinetic curve (∼2 h, Fig. S6), the styrene electronics is relevant during Ag catalysis according to the Hammett plot [34] and the KIE is somewhat significant (Fig. S9). As a further indirect probe, O2 can replace TEMPO during the Cu–catalyzed reaction to capture the intermediate coupled radical, to form ketone 4a (Fig. S7), since Cu is much active than Ag in activating the O=O bond. Notice that the metal species for CuCO3 is composed by one single atom, while AgNO3 evolves to a dimer, and that in both cases the dimerization reaction of 1a competes, which is also reflected in the equation rate. 3.2 Oxidative coupling of styrenes 1 with aryl sulfone 2 catalyzed by Cu2+–supported catalysts 3.2.1 Zeolites as supports for Cu2+ and Cu+ SACs In view that a simple Cu2+ salt such as CuCO3 is able to catalyze the coupling of styrenes 1a–m with aryl sulfone 2, we decided to explore some Cu2+–supported catalysts where the structure of the solid could somehow substitute the action of the CO3 2– anion. For that, we used zeolites with increasing order of basicity, in this case zeolites H–Y, Na–Y and Cs–Y. The latter provides a pH ∼11, similar to carbonates [47]. The Cu2+–supported zeolites were prepared by cationic exchange of the corresponding USY zeolite with the Cu(OAc)2 salt, using a solution of Cu(OAc)2 in water, since this methodology assures a good dispersion of the Cu2+ cations across the zeolite surface. Notice that Cu(OAc)2 is barely active as a catalyst under homogeneous reaction conditions for the oxidative coupling (Table S1), thus any further catalytic activity should come from the new Cu–zeolite active site. ICP–AES measurements show that the USY zeolites incorporate between 3–10 wt% of Cu depending on the zeolite (Table S2, entries 1–4). While zeolite Na–Y readily exchanges Na+ by Cu2+, H–Y and Cs–Y are more reluctant to the exchange. All zeolites were calcined at 450 °C in an oven to remove the volatiles, and the resulting materials showed the expected blue color for supported Cu2+ species. Powder X–ray diffraction (XRD) measurements confirmed the stability of the zeolite framework after incorporation of Cu2+ (Fig. S10), without any peak corresponding to copper oxide nanoparticles [48]. Diffuse reflectance UV–Visible spectrophotometry (DR UV–vis, Fig. S11) shows the appearance of the expected absorption band for Cu2+ atoms attached to the hydroxyl groups of the zeolite [49] and not for copper clusters [50], and the same absorption band for Cu2+ appears regardless if the calcination is performed under air or N2 atmosphere. In order to confirm the exclusive presence of single Cu2+ cations supported on the hydroxyl groups of the zeolite framework, X–ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), Raman and EPR measurements were performed to the calcined Cu–NaY zeolite. The deconvoluted signals for Cu 2p1/2 and Cu 2p3/2 in XPS (Fig. S12) show the only presence of Cu2+ species, since a binding energy of ∼935 eV for the Cu 2p3/2 signal and the quantitative presence of the satellite signal only visible for Cu2+, and not for either Cu+ or Cu0, is consistent with Cu2+ [51]. Besides, the Raman spectrum (Fig. S13) shows the presence of a peak at 420 cm−1, assignable to atomically isolated Cu2+ [52], and the EPR spectrum of calcined Cu-NaY (Fig. S14) clearly shows the expected signal and parameters for isolated Cu2+ cations bound to the OH groups of the zeolite framework (g ∥ = 2.39 G) [49,53]. All these results strongly support that the main species in the zeolites are atomically dispersed Cu2+ bound to the hydroxyl zeolite groups, and not reduced species, clusters or copper oxide. The catalytic results for the oxidative cross–coupling reaction of styrene 1a with phenyl sulfone 2 with the Cu2+-supported zeolites are shown in Table 2 . The pristine zeolites did not catalyze the reaction. It can be seen that the three Cu–zeolites tested gave good yields of product 3a (56–76%), even better than CuCO3 in solution under exactly the same reaction conditions (53% of 3a), and the more basic zeolite gave the best result (compare entries 1–3). Thus, the reactive trend follows the basicity order for the zeolite, the best when the zeolite framework compares to carbonate in terms of basicity. Given that the zeolites may somewhat modify the pH when exchanging the corresponding cations by Cu2+, we also prepared a Cu2+–zeolite by impregnation, instead of cationic exchange, thus fully maintaining the pH of the original zeolite. Here, CuCl2 was employed as Cu2+ source, with the same Cu loading of the exchange zeolite, in order to double check the effect of the zeolite on the catalytic Cu2+ site regardless the precursor salt employed [as for Cu(OAc)2, CuCl2 is not catalytically active under homogeneous reaction conditions, see Table S1]. The catalytic result found for CuCl2–NaY is very similar to Cu–NaY (66 vs 70 % yield of 3a, entry 4). In order to further exclude the possibility that CuO clusters may be formed inside the CuCl2–NaY, the zeolite was calcined under N2 and the corresponding DR–UVvis was recorded (Fig. S11), confirming the absence of Cu clusters but the presence, in this case, of single Cu+ cations as the main Cu species. The catalytic result for the CuCl2–NaY before and after calcination under N2 zeolite is identical, in good agreement with the redox switch between single Cu2+ and Cu+ cations during the catalytic cycle (see Fig. 4 above). These results, together, indicate that discrete monoatomic Cu2+ SACs are the catalytic sites of the zeolites. The reusability of the zeolite catalyst was tested for the oxidative cross–coupling reaction of styrene 1a with phenyl sulfone 2. Cu–NaY was employed as a solid catalyst since its higher Cu loading enables the use of lower amounts, in weight. The results show that the yield of product 3a rapidly decreases throughout the uses of the zeolite (Fig. 5 ), from a 72 to a 24 % yield. A hot filtration test was then carried out, and the results clearly show the leaching of catalytically active species from the solid to the solution, since after filtration of the Cu–NaY catalyst at ∼30 % conversion, the yield of 3a in the solution continues increasing, to be the 52 % of the total final yield. The ICP−AES analyses (Table S3) and PXRD and XPS (Fig. S15) measurements of Cu–NaY after reaction, show how most of the copper leaches from the zeolite, although the structure of the zeolite remains unaltered. These results explain the progressive loss of catalytic activity observed in the zeolite during the reuses. 3.2.2 MOFs as a support for Cu2+ SACs The observed leaching of Cu2+ into solution during the oxidative cross–coupling reaction can be easily explained by the harsh oxidative conditions employed, where not only the TEMPO and other hydroxyl radicals present in solution but also the K+ cations provided by the K2S2O2 oxidant can migrate the atomically dispersed Cu2+ species into solution. In order to have a much robust Cu2+ solid catalyst, it would be desirable to embed the Cu2+ sites inside the framework of the solid, but keeping a suitable coordination environment to permit the catalytic cycles. Since this task is not so easy in conventional inorganic solids, the use of a MOF was here considered [54–57]. In particular, the already reported MOF of formula NiII 2{NiII 4[CuII 2(Me3mpba)2]3}·54H2O; Me3mpba4− = N,N’–2,4,6–trimethyl–1,3–phenylenebis(oxamate) (Cu–MOF, Fig. 6 ) [58–60], contains accessible Cu2+ atoms in its walls, coordinated by flexible oxamate ligands to tune and stabilize the charge of the cation, according to a plethora of characterization techniques including crystal structure determination by synchrotron X–ray diffraction [58]. Besides, this MOF contains a Cu loading >10 wt%, higher than any zeolite prepared (Table S2, entry 5), and the oxamate ligands provide a suitable coordination environment to mimic the action of either carbonates or basic zeolites. The Cu–MOF was prepared according to the reported method [58] and employed as a catalyst for the oxidative cross–coupling reaction of styrene 1a with phenyl sulfone 2. The result (Table 2, entry 5) shows that the Cu–MOF is as active as the zeolites, to give a 68% of product 3a. Remarkably, the solid MOF is reusable at least 5 times without depletion in the final yield of 3a (Fig. 7 ). A hot filtration test reveals that, after filtration of the Cu–MOF catalyst at 30% conversion, the yield of 3a continues to increase up to 60%. On the contrary, the ICP–AES analysis shows that the copper loading in the catalyst after 5 uses only decreases by ∼1 wt% (Table S3). XRD and XPS measurements of Cu–MOF after reaction (Fig. S16) confirmed the stability of the solid throughout the reuses. Hence, these results indicate that copper is redeposited after cooling at room temperature, when the reaction is finished, in what is called the boomerang effect [61], allowing the reuse of the catalyst. A kinetic study with different amounts of Cu–MOF shows that the reaction order for the solid Cu catalyst is zero, as it occurs in solution (Fig. S17). This result strongly suggests that the reaction mechanism with the solid is similar to that with Cu in solution, shown in Fig. 4 above. Regarding the scope with the solid, the catalytic results with either Cu–NaY or Cu–MOF (Fig. 8 ) show that different coupling products can be obtained in even higher yields than with the homogeneous salts. These results showcase the advantages of using a metal–supported microporous solid catalyst, such as the zeolite or a MOF,[ 62–64 ] for this reaction. Since Ni could play a catalytic role in the solid but we can not disengage Ni and Cu in the MOF, we prepared and tested as a catalyst a new solid composed of Ni supported in the NaY zeolite. The Ni content is 4.5 wt%. The catalytic result with Ni–NaY, added in the reaction with a Ni content similar to that added in the Cu–MOF (Table S4), showed that the yield of product 3a with the Ni–NaY catalyst is just 1.5 %. Thus, we can say that Ni seems to be catalytically inactive for the coupling reaction of 1a and 2 when supported, at least in the zeolite, under optimized reaction conditions. 4 Conclusions The oxidative coupling of styrenes with aryl sulfones, a representative metal–catalyzed C–H activation process in solution under strong oxidant conditions and typically catalyzed by precious metal catalysts, is here catalyzed by a simple Cu2+ salt (CuCO3). A comparative study on the reaction mechanism between Cu and Ag salts catalysts is here provided, which reveals that Cu acts as a single atom while Ag acts as a dimer, after aggregation. The Cu2+ SACs have been supported in different zeolites, and although shows a higher catalytic activity than CuCO3 when the basicity of the zeolite matches that of carbonate, the solid shows a ∼50 % leaching of catalytically active species into solution during reaction. In contrast, a MOF containing the Cu2+ SACs within its framework shows a similar catalytic activity for at least five reuses. These results showcase how to replace a catalytic system based on a precious metal by a catalytic system based on an earth–abundant metal cation, in either solution or on solids, to ultimately stabilize the SAC site in the framework of a MOF despite the highly aggressive reaction conditions. coredata.dc:description: Oxidative couplings in organic synthesis are typically performed with unrecoverable precious metal catalysts in solution. Here we show that CuCO3, Cu–supported zeolites and Cu–metal organic frameworks (MOFs) can replace AgNO3 as a catalyst for the oxidative coupling of styrenes with aryl sulfones, to give styrenyl sulfones. The single Cu atoms supported in zeolites show higher catalytic activity than the Cu salt as the basicity of the zeolite framework increases, to match the carbonate salt, and when embedded directly into a MOFs´ walls with oxamate ligands (thus with the proper electronic environment) they can be recycled for at least five times without any depletion in catalytic activity. These results showcase not only the substitution of a noble metal (Ag) by an abundant metal (Cu) in a metal–catalyzed oxidative coupling reaction, but also going from a salt to a supported solid catalyst, of high significance from a sustainable point of view.

coredata.dc:title: Single–atom Cu catalysts for the oxidative coupling of styrenes with aryl sulfones: from salts and zeolites to MOFs
